items.title: Misuse of MAX_PATH
items.body:
Examples:

https://github.com/enthought/pywin32-ctypes/blob/f27d6a0000c611dfaef658ec6dbb9ea905d11deb/win32ctypes/core/ctypes/_system_information.py#L16-L19

https://github.com/enthought/pywin32-ctypes/blob/f27d6a0000c611dfaef658ec6dbb9ea905d11deb/win32ctypes/core/cffi/_system_information.py#L25-L28

Described my Microsoft:

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/fileio/naming-a-file#maximum-path-length-limitation

`In the Windows API (with some exceptions discussed in the following paragraphs), the maximum length for a path is MAX_PATH, which is defined as 260 characters.`

In other words, paths can be 260 characters long. Therefore it is wrong to allocate a buffer that is only big enough to fit 260 characters. We must allocate `MAX_PATH + 1` characters, so that the buffer will fit 260 characters plus the NULL terminator.

PS: "Characters" in Microsoft jargon refers to two-byte Unicode UTF-16 characters. It does not refer to actual bytes.

items.title: Syntax error with python 3.7
items.body:
After installing python 3.7 i get this when using keyring
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\msys64\mingw32\lib\python3.7\site-packages\keyring\backend.py", line 148, in _load_plugins
    init_func = ep.load()
  File "C:\msys64\mingw32\lib\python3.7\site-packages\entrypoints.py", line 77, in load
    mod = import_module(self.module_name)
  File "C:\msys64\mingw32\lib\python3.7\importlib\__init__.py", line 127, in import_module
    return _bootstrap._gcd_import(name[level:], package, level)
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 1006, in _gcd_import
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 983, in _find_and_load
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 967, in _find_and_load_unlocked
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 677, in _load_unlocked
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap_external>", line 728, in exec_module
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 219, in _call_with_frames_removed
  File "C:\msys64\mingw32\lib\python3.7\site-packages\keyring\backends\Windows.py", line 12, in <module>
    from win32ctypes.pywin32 import pywintypes
  File "C:\msys64\mingw32\lib\python3.7\site-packages\win32ctypes\pywin32\__init__.py", line 21, in <module>
    from win32ctypes.pywin32 import win32api
  File "C:\msys64\mingw32\lib\python3.7\site-packages\win32ctypes\pywin32\win32api.py", line 23, in <module>
    from win32ctypes.core import _common, _kernel32, _backend
  File "C:\msys64\mingw32\lib\python3.7\site-packages\win32ctypes\core\__init__.py", line 39, in <module>
    from .cffi import _advapi32, _common, _kernel32
  File "C:\msys64\mingw32\lib\python3.7\site-packages\win32ctypes\core\cffi\_advapi32.py", line 198

    ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
```
And indeed on line 198 is a newline to much, after fixing this everything worked.

I wanted to make a Pull request, but this file is not in the repo, probably build somehow?

items.title: Support lazy wrapping of win32 functions
items.body: While the current library has just a few functions wrapped when we start wrapping more and more of the win32 api importing the different core modules will become very expensive because of the import time wrapping. We need to revisit the implementation and support lazy wrapping of the functions.

items.title: win32ctypes.pywintypes missing in 0.1.0
items.body:
In jaraco/keyring#278, it appears that the changes in pywin32-ctypes 0.1.0 introduced backward-incompatible changes that cause the win32cred and/or pywintypes not to import properly, causing keyring to stop working on Windows.

More investigation is needed.

items.title: Issue pip installing v0.1.0 from pypi
items.body:
Hello,

Since the 0.1.0 wheel was published to pypi, I have been getting this error when trying to pip install on Windows.

It appears that the VERSION file is not being included in the package?

``` 
Collecting pywin32-ctypes; sys_platform == "win32" (from keyring>=5.6->msrestazure~=0.4.7->azure-keyvault==0.2.0->-r M:\GeneralVS15-055\_work\21\s\myrepo\requirements.txt (line 2))
   Using cached pywin32-ctypes-0.1.0.tar.gz
     Complete output from command python setup.py egg_info:
     Traceback (most recent call last):
       File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
       File "M:\GeneralVS15-055\_work\_temp\pip-build-uwujm7ug\pywin32-ctypes\setup.py", line 7, in <module>
         os.path.join(HERE, 'VERSION')).read().strip()
     FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'M:\\GeneralVS15-055\\_work\\_temp\\pip-build-uwujm7ug\\pywin32-ctypes\\VERSION'
     
     ----------------------------------------
 ##[error]Command "python setup.py egg_info" failed with error code 1 in M:\GeneralVS15-055\_work\_temp\pip-build-uwujm7ug\pywin32-ctypes\

 ##[error]Process completed with exit code 1 and had 1 error(s) written to the error stream.
```
Thanks,
Andrew

### Workaround
Just add this line to your requirements.txt
```
pywin32-ctypes == 0.0.1
```

items.title: Add Tests for BeginUpdateResource, UpdateResource, EndUpdateResource
Support Python 3.5 and 3.6
items.body: Currently our setup,py claims no support for Python 3.5 and 3.6 we should update the code and test build to check also for the latest Python versions

items.title: Is this project dead?
items.body: We have some additional APIs to add, and would like to see a new release on pypi. However, if this is dead, we'll just fork it and push to pypi ourselves. Let me know, thanks!

items.title: Segfault on windows 10 with cffi
items.body:
The segfault is shown https://ci.appveyor.com/project/itziakos/pywin32-ctypes/build/1.0.21/job/2t7qda654rqf72dh. 

The segfault can be replicated by running the `test_read_simple` test in `TestCred`. I was able to replicate locally with Windows 10 and python 3.4 and 2.7.

It looks that there is a problem when calling CredRead (https://github.com/enthought/pywin32-ctypes/blob/master/win32ctypes/pywin32/win32cred.py#L46)

items.title: Update to use cffi 1.3.0
items.body: The new cffi 1.3.0 support the `WINAPI` call convention so it should be really good to have this in to avoid  possible problems with callback functions in 32bit systems

items.title: EnumResourceTypes result is not right
items.body: in pywin32 the EnumResourceTypes method a list of resource_types where each item is either a name (i.e. str) of a type_id (i.e. int). The ctypes implementation does not perform the right checks and will always return an int.

items.title: Drop-in replacement
items.body:
Can pywin32-ctypes run as a drop-in replacement for pywin32 so 

```
import win32api
```

just works without modifying any code?

items.title: Split the package into two separate subpackages
items.body:
We should restructure the file organization as follow:
- win32ctypes.core.ctypes: thin ctypes wrapper (3 levels to allow win32ctypes.core.cffi later on)
- win32ctypes.pywin32: the pywin32 compat

items.title: Add basic documentation for the methods in win32api
